Award.AwardTitle: The Role of Environmentally Persistent Free Radicals in the Chemistry of Airborne PM2.5
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Environmental Chemical Sciences (ECS) program of the Division of Chemistry will support the research program of Prof. Barry Dellinger of Louisiana State University. Prof. Dellinger and his students will study the environmental impact of Environmentally Persistent Free Radicals (EPFRs) in airborne fine particles. Prof. Dellinger's group has detected organic free radicals associated with freshly sampled airborne particles that are less than 2.5 micrometers in diameter (PM2.5), which can persist in air for several days after collection. The chemical and toxicological characteristics of these radicals are similar to radicals associated with the tar in cigarette smoke, and detected in samples of combustion-generated PM. Since the radicals are both stable toward decomposition and resistant to reaction with air, they are referred to as environmentally persistent and may serve as effective reducing agents in aqueous solution. Using EPR spectroscopy, EPFRs formed from dosing samples of PM2.5 with suspected EPFR precursors, will be compared to EPFRs formed on controlled surrogate particles containing different transition metals. The decay and lifetimes of the observed EPFRs will be determined as a function of temperature, humidity, and solar irradiation. EPFR-induced formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) under biological conditions will be determined. The potential for EPFRs to participate in selected atmospheric chemistry will be evaluated. Reactions with NO and O3 will be studied to determine if EPFRs result in depletion or formation of these pollutants as well as formation of nitro-/oxy-PAH, other oxygenated species, and secondary radicals.

As part of this project, Dr. Dellinger and his students will present project and research summaries to science-affiliated clubs and undergraduate programs. Collaborative research and interdisciplinary training of graduate students in chemistry, combustion, and environmental health sciences research will be conducted through the LSU Superfund Research Center. The PI is committed to student presentations at national/international meetings and their participation in several high impact education and outreach groups and programs already established at LSU, including the Superfund Research Program seminars and exchange program with biomedical research collaborators.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The concerns over the impacts airborne particulate matter (particularly PM2.5) on the human health gain increased attention over the past decade. Inhalation of PM2.5 has been linked to increased mortality and cardiovascular and respiratory diseases. These effects are due to PM2.5 capability to penetrate deep within the lungs and transport of PM2.5 constituents such as polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs), metals, carbonaceous material, and volatile organic compounds (VOCs). A new hypothesis of the toxic effects of PM is associated with the presence of Environmentally Persistent Free Radicals (EPFRs) as major causative agents of inflammation and oxidative stress. The chemical and toxicological characteristics of these radicals are similar to radicals associated with the tar in cigarette smoke and detected by us in samples of combustion generated particulate matter (PM). Our data indicate the radicals are formed and stabilized by chemisorption of substituted aromatic species with redox-active transition metals. Because the radicals are both stable toward decomposition and resistant to reaction with air, we refer to them as environmentally persistent free radicals (EPFRs). The main class of EPFRs we have observed to on PM are semiquinone-type species, which are known to be reducing agents in aqueous solution. This suggests they have the potential to react with other ambient air pollutants such as NOx, O3, and also O2 to form nitro- and oxy-PAH.

 

The notable feature of PM2.5 to generate reactive-oxygen species (ROS) such as superoxide (O2•-), hydroxyl radical, hydrogen peroxide etc. in physiological environment has been shown (cf. Figure. 1). These reactions are based on the redox cycling of EPFRs present on the surface of PM2.5. Earlier studies of synthetic surrogate PM sample containing only EPFRs have shown analogous behavior.  EPFRs associated with PM2.5 have been identified as possessing 3 different lifetime behaviors: relatively short lived with a lifetime of days, moderate stable EPFRs with lifetime of month and indefinite EPFRs with no decay characteristics (Figure 2). The activity of EPFRs associated with PM2.5, as well as laboratory prepared surrogate radicals were also tested to agains atmospheric gasses and radical scavengers such as NOx (NO or NO2): an elimination of the radicals in the model EPFR system and PM2.5 was observed under addition of nitric oxides, NOx resulting from the reaction between paramagnetic scavengers and EPFRs forming nitroso compounds.

Solar exposure of PM results in new radicals formation on the surface of PM2.5 as well as on the surrogate samples. In fact the EPFR samples have shown a diurnal behavior with radicals decaying during the dark period and regenerating during solar exposure.

 

Vast majority of the PM2.5 samples demonstrated constant generation of reactive oxygen species in physiological conditions which is believed to lead to causing oxidative stress in living organism. A generalized ROS generation cycle is presented in Figure 3.

 

This research unambiguously shows that the atmospheric pollutant PM2.5 must be rather considered an EPFR-metal system than an adsorbed molecular species which is important to evaluate in future the reactivity and toxicology of PM.
